answers.answer: Your BP is high now and does need some intervention. It is not unusual for BP to increase as you get older. 130/90 was at the upper range of normal so has probably been climbing through your life.High cholesterol combined with high BP is a risk factor for heart attack. Contrary to much belief, the amount of cholesterol in your blood does not depend on how much cholesterol is in your diet. Cholesterol is made in the liver! Your Doctor will probably need to give you a statin (simvostatin) which inhibits the production of cholesterol in the liver.Both statins and ACE inhibitors have a protective effect on the heart.You should probably be checked for diabetes too. The triad og high BP, High Cholesterol,and diabetes is part of "metabolic syndrome" which leads to a high risk of heart attack.... RD

question: Male, 48, 168 pounds, never smoke, alcohol moderate, excercise adequate.I went in for an unrelated problem and upon checking my BP, the nurse said to forget about my reason for coming here, you BP is 150/110.  I was shocked because I've always had and one year ago had 130/90ish BP and we checked it again and readings were the same.  Doc came in, went over diet,(very good), history(average), excercise(adequate), medication(taking Naproxen on/off for last 12 days).  Doc wanted to get me on ACE inhibitor imediately.  I delayed and came back the next day for a check.  BP was a bit lower but still high.  Started 10mg day Lisinopril and ordered a blood test.  In a few days, the blood test was in and results were high cholesterol.  I was again shocked as my cholesterol was high in 2001 but through major changes in diet, (no pasta, no white bread, reduced sugar, etc.), reduced it in 2003 to slightly under normal.  Doc wanted me on Vytorin 10/20 and I took a few but decided to wait.I have researched and looked back to try to figure out what is going on and here are my conclusions.  I have never been a real hard exerciser.  I would run 1 mile, or walk 4, or ride 5 or 6, but only 3 times a week.  The rest of the time I would be sitting at this computer working.  So I have started to excercise 2 to 3 times a day.  15 min run, 30 to 60 min walk, hard bike ride, etc.  This is based on an experience my wife and I had 2 years ago where for 3 months, we were off the computer, and did manual work all day.  We both ate more calories but both lost 10 pounds in those three months.  At the end of the day were were worn out but felt great.  I think this lack of getting revved up throughout the day was responsible for my Cholesterol and possibly BP.Continued...
title: Increase in Pressure and Cholesterol in 1 and 3 years
